title: How to Make a Dual Layer Chess Board

steps.headline: Gather your supplies.
steps.description: These are listed below in the Thing's You'll Need section.

steps.headline: Measure out a square of wood (at least 9" by 9"), and mark it with a pencil.
Cut out your square with the saw, following the pencil lines you drew.
Inside your cut-out square, draw an 8" by 8" square using the ruler and pencil.
Divide the square into 1" by 1" squares (64 of them), with the ruler and pencil.

Use the 1" straight chisel and mallet to cut out EVERY OTHER square on the chess board, hitting the chisel with one or two solid hits straight into the pencil line all around each square, and then levering out the top layer of wood.
steps.description: With plywood, the layer should come out easily, and the second layer easily distinguishable from the top.

steps.headline: Sand the entire chess board lightly to remove splinters.
steps.description: If you want sharper angles, stop sanding. If you want soft corners, continue sanding until the corners take on the desired rounded shape.

steps.headline: Wipe down the entire board thoroughly with a dry rag.
If you are using wood stain and paint, stain first.
steps.description: To stain, select the desired color of wood stain, make sure your board is clean, and apply the stain with a rag. The rag will be permanently stained. Follow the directions on the stain to achieve a darker color, if desired.

steps.headline: Paint after stain has dried, or if only using paint, simply make sure your board is clean.
steps.description: For two tones, paint the entire board the color that the RAISED squares will be. When that paint has dried, carefully brush in paint in the LOWER squares.

steps.headline: Set in a safe place to dry, LOWER squares facing up.

text: Gather your supplies. These are listed below in the Thing's You'll Need section. Measure out a square of wood (at least 9" by 9"), and mark it with a pencil.  Cut out your square with the saw, following the pencil lines you drew.  Inside your cut-out square, draw an 8" by 8" square using the ruler and pencil.  Divide the square into 1" by 1" squares (64 of them), with the ruler and pencil.  Use the 1" straight chisel and mallet to cut out EVERY OTHER square on the chess board, hitting the chisel with one or two solid hits straight into the pencil line all around each square, and then levering out the top layer of wood. With plywood, the layer should come out easily, and the second layer easily distinguishable from the top. Sand the entire chess board lightly to remove splinters. If you want sharper angles, stop sanding. If you want soft corners, continue sanding until the corners take on the desired rounded shape. Wipe down the entire board thoroughly with a dry rag.  If you are using wood stain and paint, stain first. To stain, select the desired color of wood stain, make sure your board is clean, and apply the stain with a rag. The rag will be permanently stained. Follow the directions on the stain to achieve a darker color, if desired. Paint after stain has dried, or if only using paint, simply make sure your board is clean. For two tones, paint the entire board the color that the RAISED squares will be. When that paint has dried, carefully brush in paint in the LOWER squares. Set in a safe place to dry, LOWER squares facing up.
